awd_titl_txt: CSEDI Collaborative Research: Deciphering the LLSVP-plume relationship
awd_abstract_narration:
Much of our view of mantle evolution is shaped by our current knowledge of mantle convection and plume dynamics; examples include hotspot volcanism--including large igneous provinces--and mantle mixing. By gaining a deeper understanding of how, where, and why plumes form, and their composition and their relationship to the deep interior's large low shear wave velocity structures (LLSVPs) under Africa and the Pacific, the PIs will make a significant step towards understanding the dynamical and geochemical evolution of the mantle. Their efforts should provide a basis to better understand the three-dimensional flow structure surrounding LLSVPs and where, how, and why plumes form. This may help answer the question: How is the relationship between plumes and LLSVPs reflected in hotspot lavas such as those found in Hawaii? The new research directions will enrich cross-fertilization between the fields of mantle dynamics and geochemistry and contribute to the growing body of work on mantle plumes and LLSVPs. The PIs are engaged in a number of activities aimed at education and training at all levels. The PIs have and will continue to engage undergraduate students, including those from underrepresented groups in their research activities. As part of this proposal the PIs aim to augment the content associated with related Wikipedia entries and develop a series of educational films to post on specifically dedicated YouTube channels. The lab lends itself to site visits by elementary, middle school and high school students. PI Lithgow-Bertelloni intends to continue providing lab tours and opportunities for elementary and middle-school children to be involved in simple experiments.

Amongst the most enigmatic aspects of the Earth's deep interior are the anomalous large low shear wave velocity provinces (LLSVPs) under Africa and the Pacific. The origin, composition, and dynamics of these provinces remain controversial. For example, it has been suggested that plumes predominantly form at the edges of LLSVPs and that entrained material from LLSVPs explains the distinct chemical asymmetries found at certain hotspots. The PIs are proposing an experimental fluid dynamical study to explore how three proposed LLSVP structures control and interact with mantle plumes. These three structures represent the range of LLSVP formation hypotheses so far proposed: a) purely thermal; b) dense and deformable; c) undeformable and uncoupled. They will use state-of-the-art visualization tools, including scanning particle image velocimetry and thermometry to measure the three-dimensional temperature and flow fields, laser induced fluorescence, and Lagrangian analysis tools to locate plumes and quantify entrainment to very high spatial and temporal resolutions. The PIs seek to test both location control and whether entrainment at the edges explains the observed chemical asymmetry in hotspot lavas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: STUDIES OF THE EARTHS DEEP INT

por.por_cntn:
The origin, composition, and dynamics of the LLSVPs (large low shear wave velocity provinces), which are continent-sized bodies located at the base of the Earth?s mantle, remain controversial. A major goal of the grant was to understand the relationship between mantle plumes and LLSVPs. This was explored in two ways: 1) three different LLSVP geometries?purely thermal, dense and deformable, undeformable and uncoupled?were examined in analogue tank experiments by lead PI C. Lithgow-Bertelloni to evaluate how the LLSVPs interact with the mantle and how mantle plumes emerge from the LLSVPs; and 2) PI M. Jackson used existing published literature to test whether geochemical compositions of plumes (i.e., high 3He/4He) relates to mantle domains entrained from the LLSVPs by the hottest plumes. In order to evaluate the second aspect of the grant, a database of maximum 3He/4He values at global hotspots was compiled and a new method was developed for calculating the temperature of a mantle plume using a thermodynamic model for converting seismic velocity structure to temperature. We find that hot hotspots have high 3He/4He and buoyancy flux, while cold hotspots do not. However, a major outcome of this study is that most hotspots are not actually hot: 55% of hotspots are sourced by mantle domains that are too cold to upwell. This finding raises new questions that will need to be addressed in future studies: How do cold plumes upwell, and are they sourced in the upper mantle?        

The implications of the proposed work reach beyond the geochemistry of oceanic basalts, which is the specialization of PI Jackson. This grant funded an interdisciplinary collaboration with PI Lithgow-Bertelloni and her PhD student to develop to understand mantle convection by bridging constraints from geochemistry and geodynamics. By drawing on strengths of two different fields?geochemistry (PI Jackson) and geodynamics (Lithgow-Bertelloni)?the PIs were able to place tighter constraints on mantle potential temperatures of plumes that we compare to petrologically-determined mantle potential temperatures. This work is of broad interest across fields of Earth Science, as evidence by our capstone publication in the journal Science.

In total the PI published 13 peer-reviewed papers with partial support from this grant, and all of the publications specifically acknowledged this grant. Additionally, this grant provided resources for the PI to serve as a mentor to three young scientists: a UCSB postdoc, a UCSB graduate student, and a UCLA graduate student. Mentorship of all three mentees was successful, and lead to development of manuscripts?all first-authored by mentees?that directly relate to the goals of this grant. Finally, the PI interviewed on a recent Podcast, ?Geology Bites,? to discuss the implications of research on hotspots for the origin of mantle heterogeneity (January 2022).
